paragraphs.name: 80f4
paragraphs.text: Jason Concepcion: If Russell Westbrook doesn’t win the MVP award, future generations will look back and wonder how we took leave of our senses. The context — James Harden’s win shares, the Rockets’ record, Westbrook’s high usage rate, Kawhi’s two-way punch — will fall away with the intervening years. What will remain is this: RUSSELL WESTBROOK AVERAGED A TRIPLE-DOUBLE FOR AN ENTIRE SEASON AND DIDN’T WIN THE MVP. That’s the headline that will travel across the ages. Russ, as you know, broke Oscar’s 55-year-old single-season triple-double record, something once considered impossible. He’s a basketball Paul Bunyan, a giant, walking the earthly plane, cutting down entire forests by himself. At one time, up to only a few weeks ago, I was pretty sure the MVP was James Harden. Some part of me still leans that way. But Russ convinced me. Basically by grabbing me around the neck and refusing to let go until I say “You are the MVP,” whether I really believe it or not. So that’s it. Westbrook is the MVP. You can let go now.

paragraphs.text: Harden should be MVP. Don’t need my point guard grabbing 10 boards a game. Harden’s extra assist over Westbrook is much more valuable than Westbrook’s 2 boards over Harden.

paragraphs.text: The Thunder lost Kevin Durant and Serge Ibaka, yet STILL made the playoffs comfortably in the super competitive West. This fact is more impressive than any stat/efficiency rating/win share/time share/etc.

b6e8a25e7b61.title: Lebron is the best player in the league, there’s no doubt about that.

content.subtitle: The only argument for Lebron is how absolutely incompetent Kyrie is at running at offense, and his admittedly crazy counting stats which…

paragraphs.text: Lebron is the best player in the league, there’s no doubt about that. But he definitely does not deserve to win the MVP this year. He played 2 or 3 more minutes a game than all those guys, has two other all stars on his team, and for all that they have the 5th best record in the league. One more loss and they’re the 8th best record.

848b27237488.title: I liked Bill’s theory that the middle-class of the league is so strong, that the top teams can’t…

paragraphs.text: I liked Bill’s theory that the middle-class of the league is so strong, that the top teams can’t really take a break. That being said, the MVP is LeBron James. That cavs team would’ve won 28 games this year without him. With him, they are going to make the Finals for a *third* straight year. He could have averaged a triple double if he really wanted…

a831bafaf743.title: To be fair, neither did Robertson when he averaged a triple double.

paragraphs.name: ad1e
paragraphs.text: To be fair, neither did Robertson when he averaged a triple double. There is clear precedent for Westbrook not winning it. Plus, despite the spin put on it, Westbrook has a better supporting cast, yet its Harden and the Rockets who have far exceeded preseason expectations.

81e5767e76dd.title: I like that there’s not a case here for Kawhi.

paragraphs.text: I like that there’s not a case here for Kawhi. I’ve studied it long and hard and I genuinely don’t see one there. The numbers don’t measure up, the wins don’t measure up, and he doesn’t fit any historical MVP profile. I can buy him being on the ballot but I can’t find a case for putting him #1.

paragraphs.text: I don’t understand how the two leading MVP candidates can be playing each other in the first round as 3 and 6 seeds. Of course, if triple doubles are arbitrary (although less so than Double-Doubles) then I’d wager then so are wins.

Now look up true shooting percentage for this season (which apparently isn’t an arbitrary stat…

6f132ef6419b.title: With this MVP race I feel the media has turned greatness into a math problem and algorithm.

paragraphs.text: With this MVP race I feel the media has turned greatness into a math problem and algorithm. Which is a shame in that case people can easily manipulate and say this or that stat is arbitrary. Take away all the numbers for just a moment and just see with your eyes and heart as a human being, Russ has given the fans unforgettable moments in the season…

We might not see a season like this ever again. The only reason to give it to Harden at this point is because his team won 8 more games. However, when you consider the fact that Houston might have…

cc31a8760257.title: Why isn’t the MVP a Warrior?

paragraphs.name: d371
paragraphs.text: Why isn’t the MVP a Warrior? Twelve teams have won 67 games in NBA history. Nine had the MVP and three had the runner-up. Who cares about 55 wins for the Rox or 51 for the Cavs? Those are middling playoff records just as much as OKC. If wins are your big criteria, Harden and LeBron are out along with Russ and a Warrior should win.

virtuals.subtitle: Anyway, just a thought I had. (Note — I am NOT a Westbrook hater, I’ve been enjoying his game since he came into the league).

paragraphs.text: As far as definition of MVP goes, what about this: The MVP is the player who did the most to increase his team’s odds of winning the title.
